results.title: From sand to celluloid
results.creator_credit: Bill McCrow, Darlene Johnson, Richard Frankland, Rima Tamou, Sally Riley, Warwick Thornton, Franco Di Chiera, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: An impressive collection of Australian short films by First Nations filmmakers which explore the history and contradictions of First Nations identity. Richard Frankland’s “No Way to Forget” is the story of a young man, working on the Royal Commission on Black Deaths in Custody, who drives home to Melbourne and is haunted by the ghosts of the dead. dead. In Sally Riley’s “Fly Peewee Fly!”, a young boy teaches his white grandmother and his Koorie father a few lessons on perspective. Rima Tamou’s “Round Up” is a tender story about two country boys who discover that their racial differences are not so acute when they are confronted with the multiculturalism and subcultures of the inner-city. In “Two Bob Mermaid” Darlene Johnson presents a beautifully filmed story about a young girl who can pass for white in a racially divided 1957 Australia. Warwick Thornton’s “Payback” presents a surreal story of a young convict who has to obey tribal lore as much as he does white law. Bill McCrow’s “Black Man Down” explores contemporary awareness of the lessons and spirituality of the past.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill McCrow, Darlene Johnson, Richard Frankland, Rima Tamou, Sally Riley, Warwick Thornton, Franco Di Chiera, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australian Film Commission

results.title: Underdog
results.creator_credit: Paul Cox, Robert Colvin and Illumination Films (AU)
results.brief_description: The dingo is currently hunted as a pest in all states of Australia, and its survival as a pure breed is endangered. This documentary presents a case for the dingo’s protection. It looks at the history of the dingo, its place in First Nations peoples’ cultures and communities, and at the current dingo eradication program. Interviews people who are involved with the conservation of dingoes, including people who keep them as pets. This is another early film from renowned Australian filmmaker, Paul Cox.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Cox, Robert Colvin and Illumination Films (AU)

results.title: Conflict of interest (D)
results.creator_credit: Tony Wellington, Ian MacArthur and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The basis of this film is the National Park and Wildlife Services kangaroo control and management program. The kangaroo is shown, historically, as a source of food for First Nations peoples, as game and a source of income for the first Europeans and today as a symbol of Australia. The Kangaroo Management Program is discussed at length. It aims to ensure the conservation of all species of macropods, the investigation of agricultural damage and the best use of product derived from culling kangaroos. Statistical information on kangaroo culling is presented diagramatically.

results.title: Western Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Holiday”.
Experience the highlights of Western Australia beginning with the wildlife and good food at Margaret River, visit the Pinnacles, enjoy a range of sporting activities at Merribrook, join a cattle muster at El Questro or a novelty gypsy caravan tour, explore the Spanish architecture at the New Norcia mission, visit the Pilbara and picturesque Broome or board a yacht to explore remote sections of Western Australia’s spectacular coastline.

results.title: Inventing reality
results.creator_credit: Michael Grant, Richard Meech and Biniman Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Millennium: tribal wisdom and the modern world”.
Have our needs for certainty and objectivity in our lives closed off the magical influence of the natural world? Is there a balance to strike? Follow narrator David Maybury-Lewis to the Huichol Indian villages of central Mexico to witness a Mexican doctor and a tribal shaman battling an epidemic of a rare strain of deadly measles. Then visit a cancer treatment centre in Toronto. Through these two examples understand how the certainties of science can combine with natural conceptions of physical disease. Then travel to Australia to ask the question: is reality something we shape - as some Australian First Nations peoples believe - or vice-versa?

results.title: Out of darkness
results.brief_description: Robyn Williams narrates this history of First Nations peoples in Australia and the archaeological discoveries that have pieced together this history. Since the 1960’s our knowledge of the length of human occupation in the Australian continent has greatly increased, and it is now recognised that First Nations peoples in Australia are inheritors of the longest surviving culture in the world.

results.title: The Killing times
results.brief_description: In August 1928, in the desert of Central Australia, seven white Australians murdered seventeen people of the Walbiri tribe. This became known as the Coniston Massacre. This video dramatises the massacre and the subsequent Federal Inquiry, as well as the eventual victory of the Walbiri for the right to return and live where they were born. The cast includes Ray Barrett, Max Gillies and Martin Vaughan. Narrated by Bob Plasto.

results.title: Koorie culture, Koorie control
results.creator_credit: Russell Porter, Lucy MacLaren, Film Victoria, Mozo Films and Museum Victoria
results.brief_description: Through a series of interviews with members of Victorian First Nations communities, this video gives a broad understanding of the unwritten and undocumented history of Victoria. Issues such as the protection of sites of significance, the return of skeletal remains to their home and the significance of passing on Koorie culture to the young are all raised in this program, which stresses the importance of First Nations peoples’ land rights.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Russell Porter, Lucy MacLaren, Film Victoria, Mozo Films and Museum Victoria

results.title: For all the world to see: a portrait of Professor Fred Hollows
results.creator_credit: Megan McMurchy, Pat Fiske, ABC-TV (Australia) and Bower Bird Films
results.brief_description: Fred Hollows was a controversial, larger-than-life character who was abrasive, determined, flamboyant, unconventional and full of contradictions. Some loved him, some hated him. The style of this film, like the man, is direct, forthright, warts and all. Rather than conquer and convert, his philosophy was to train people to help themselves and this film documents his work in Eritrea, Nepal and here in Australia. Included is film shot during recent expeditions, archival material and interviews and glimpses of him at home and on the road. “For all the world to see” is bold, wry, intimate and ultimately a very moving tribute to an extraordinary life.

results.title: Australia's people and patterns of work
results.creator_credit: Greg Shepherd, Mervyn Dober, Appleseed Productions and Focus Ausio-Visual Services
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Australia at work”.
A four part series examining Australians’ attitudes to work and to changes in the Australian workplace. The first part of this episode examines the history of industry and labour in Australia, as well as looking at the current diversity of occupations and work throughout the country. Australians involved in unpaid labour are interviewed, particularly women working in domestic labour. The second half of the video examines the difficulties and discrimination encountered by women, migrants, First Nations people, and people with disabilities in the labour market.
